q1.value: Evaluations of postoperative transitions in care for older adults

q3.value: Older adults have surgery at a higher rate than any other age group. Older adults are at risk of poor outcomes after surgery, including increased time in hospital, complications, worsened disability, and difficulty living independently at home. These increased risks also result in higher costs to the healthcare system. The transition out of hospital is a particularly vulnerable time for older adults and their caregivers. To develop and test new interventions to better support people with frailty transitioning out of hospital after surgery, we must first understand what a successful transition in care means to older adults and their caregivers. To address this knowledge gap, we will first summarize how researchers currently evaluate successful transitions in care for older adults leaving hospital by reviewing and synthesizing the scientific literature. Synthesizing current literature will provide us with an opportunity to determine the extent to which current research aligns with patient values and priorities.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Scoping Review

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A comprehensive search strategy will be developed with a research librarian. We will apply it to the databases; Medline (Ovid), EMBASE (Ovid), CINHAL, and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL). The searches in the electronic databases will be carried out from their respective inception dates to October 3, 2019. Reference lists and grey literature will be examined. Abstracts will also be included as they should detail primary outcomes. The literature search will not impose language or date restrictions. 

Study Selection: Titles and abstracts will be screened using a liberal accelerated approach. To ensure that all studies are screened in duplicate, all abstracts that are identified as an exclusion will be reviewed by a second reviewer. Next, full texts will be reviewed in duplicate followed by data extraction. Disagreements will be resolved through consensus. 

Data will be extracted independently by two authors using a pre-piloted data charting form. Investigators will ensure their extraction is consistent and aligned with the research question. Charting will be iterative and the form will be updated with continuous data extraction.

attributes.title: Replicating Morehead et al (2017) Study 4 with LPA

q1.value: Identifying Subpoplations of Learning who make different restudy decision on category learning task.

q3.value: This study is a replication and extension of Morehead, Dunlosky, & Foster (2017) Study 4. We received the bird category learning task from Dunlosky and will begin by attempting to replicate their results. We will also extend the previous findings by running and additionally analysis on the data where instead of identifying learner subpopulations through correlations between restudy decisions and metacognitive judgments, we will run LPA.

q4.value:
1. We will replicate the results of Morehead at all and find a bimodal distribution for the correlation between restudy decisions and metacognitive judgments. 
2. When running the LPA we expect 4 groups will be identified, one that focuses easy items, one that focuses hard items, one that chooses to restudy almost everything and one that chooses to restudy almost nothing. 
3. We expect group membership will be consistent across the Morehead and LPA categorization methods. 
4. We expect good agreement between participants self-reported restudy strategy and the strategy suggested by the LPA.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will be entirely correlational and analysis will use LPA.

Separate novel and previously learned birds

- For the LPA we are going to do a within-participants, median split on their confidence judgements to seperate things they said were high confidence vs. low confidence.
- People with correlations > .5 = study easy, < -.5 = study hard

- Used to help us determine which number of subgroups bests represents the data. 
- AIC, BIC, & ABIC (smaller numbers are better)
- LMT and BLR Tests are significance test of k vs k-1 groups. 

Testing Membership Consistency - To determine if the LPA, Correlation, and Self-Reported membership assignments are in agreement will test inter-rater reliability with Cohen’s Kappa, with the the membership identifications methods treated at the raters.

attributes.title: Test of Associative Memory in the Double-Item Method Directed Forgetting

q1.value: Test of Associative Memory in the Double-Item Method Directed Forgetting

q2.value: Pelin Tan, William Hockley, Colin M. MacLeod

q3.value: Recognition of words followed by Remember instructions (TBR items) is higher than recognition of words followed by Forget instructions (TBF items). This effect is called the directed forgetting effect and has been explored using an item-method directed forgetting paradigm. We will investigate the cognitive mechanisms of this effect by using word-pairs that are either intentionally or unintentionally associated (associative recognition). We will also examine item recognition for each word to replicate the findings of Tan et al. (under review).

q4.value:
For item recognition, we hypothesize that memory for mixed-cue R items will be better than for pure-cue R items. Memory for mixed-cue F items will also be better than for pure-cue R items. These findings will provide a replication of Tan, Ensor, Hockley, Harrison, and Wilson (2019, under review) in a new sample. 

For associative recognition, our predictions for the pure-cue conditions are clear. We hypothesize that associative memory will be the best for the pairs in the pure-cue R condition because participants have to remember both words. We predict that associative recognition will be greater for pairs in the pure-cue R condition than the pure-cue F condition, demonstrating a directed forgetting effect. However, based on previous studies (Bancroft, Hockley, and Farquhar, 2013; Jou, 2010), we predict that associative recognition for the pure-cue F pairs will still be above chance. 

Our hypotheses for the mixed-cue conditions are less clear. Pairs in this condition (mixed-cue R and mixed-cue F) will demonstrate more associative recognition than the pure-cue F pairs but less than for the pure-cue R pairs. 

We predict to find a directed forgetting effect in both pure-cue and mixed-cue conditions for item and associative recognition. For item recognition and associative recognition, we do not expect to find an interaction between cue type (R vs. F) and cue condition (pure vs. mixed) based on Tan et al. (2019, under review), indicating no difference in the magnitude of the directed forgetting effect.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study design is repeated measures. 

For item recognition, we will conduct a 2(Cue Condition: Pure vs. Mixed) x 2(Cue Type: R vs. F) repeated measures ANOVA. Although we do not predict to find an interaction, we will follow up our analysis with a priori paired samples t-tests to determine performance differences between cue type and cue condition pairs for both intact and rearranged pairs. 

For associative recognition, we will conduct a 2 (Test Pair: Intact vs. Rearranged) x 2(Cue Condition: Pure vs. Mixed) x 2(Cue Type: R vs. F) repeated measures ANOVA. Although we do not predict to find an interaction, we will follow up our analysis with a priori paired samples t-tests to determine performance differences between cue type and cue condition pairs for both intact and rearranged pairs.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through a Research Experiences Group (REG) website called SONA. They will receive 0.5 credits as rumination for their participation. This credit will apply towards extra marks on their choice of courses. Participants will be at least 18 years old and provide fluency in English. Only participants who participated previously in a directed forgetting study will be excluded. .

q13.value: This is a within-subjects study, meaning that participants will view all of the experimental conditions. We will collect data from a total of 52 participants for this study.

q14.value: We used the software program R Studio to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .3 at the standard .05 alpha. We obtained this effect size from previous studies of directed forgetting and associative words.

q15.value: We will stop data collection once we reach 52 participants. If any participant needs to be removed, they will be replaced. Data will not be analyzed until 52 participants are collected.

question.value:
We will manipulate cue type by presenting different words/instructions after each word. The two levels of this categorical variable are: Remember (R) cue or Forget (F) cue.
We will manipulate cue condition by changing the type of memory cue each word is presented with. For example, a word could be paired with another word that was followed by the same cue type as the original word (e.g., both words followed by an R) or it could be paired with another word that was followed a different cue (e.g., one word followed by an R and the other by an F). The two levels of this categorical variable are: Pure or Mixed condition. 
We will manipulate the word-pair condition by presenting the pairs either intact (the original study presentation) or rearranged (one of the words from the original pair are paired with a new word from the same condition). The two levels of this categorical variable are: Intact or Rearranged pairs.

The test will be an associative recognition memory test. Word pairs will be presented either intact (same two words presented together at test) or rearranged (each word presented at study, but not together). The outcome variable will be the hit rates. Participants will be asked "did you see these two words together at study?". They will respond yes or no on the keyboard. A collective false alarm rate will be calculated across all experimental conditions.

we will use a 2 (Cue: Remember vs. Forget) x 2 (Condition: Pure vs. Mixed) repeated measures ANOVA with both factors within subjects to analyze our results. We will follow up our significant interactions with paired samples t-tests. We predict that the interaction may not be significant. We plan to run a priori paired samples t-tests to compare associative memory recognition between pure and mixed conditions, because this is the critical test to answer our questions based on our manipulations (how much associative information participants retain when the cues are presented in pure condition vs. mixed condition). 
We will also analyze trial-by-trial data using logistic regression based on Winter, B. (2013). This may be reported in the future publication as the primary analysis since ANOVA is not appropriate for analyzing categorical data. We predict that our findings both statistical analyses will complement each other.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the paired samples t-tests suggest the results are significantly different.

q22.value:
Participants will be excluded based on accuracy rates. Accuracy rates will be calculated by Hit Rates - False Alarm Rates. Only data for the Remember items will be used to exclude participants. This is because, if a participant was following the test instructions in a perfect world, their score for the R items would be 100% while F items would be at 0%. 
We will calculate a collective False Alarm Rate for all experimental conditions. This constant will be subtracted from the Remember item Hit Rate to obtain the accuracy rate. Any participant at floor (accuracy rate = 0) will be excluded. We will calculate floor also by mean - 2SD and any participant at floor will be excluded.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete all of the trials, they will be excluded.

q25.value: Tan, P., Ensor, T.M., Hockley, W.E., Harrison, G.W., & Wilson, D.E. (under review). In support of selective rehearsal: double-item presentation in item-method directed forgetting. Psychonomic Bulletin & Review. Submitted Oct 15, 2019. Revision submitted February 1, 2020.

attributes.title: Responses and Behavior in Romantic Relationships

q1.value: Responses and Behavior in Romantic Relationships

q3.value:
Conflict, a disagreement or incompatibility between two or more people, is a pervasive phenomenon (Cahn, 1992; Shantz, 1987), especially within the context of romantic relationships. Although romantic relationship conflict is normative, with conflict occurring daily (Laursen, 1995), it can also be costly (Richards, Bulter, and Gross, 2003). Relationship conflict occurs in response to personality clashes or negative emotional reactions between romantic partners (Cahn, 1992). How couples interact and resolve their disputes is a fundamental determinant of relationship functioning (McNulty, O’Mara, and Karney, 2008). Furthermore, impulsive traits, such as negative urgency, leave individuals vulnerable to conflict. Negative urgency is the tendency to act out in response to negative emotional states (e.g., anger; Whiteside and Lynam, 2001). Individuals high in negative urgency are poor at regulating their emotional reactions to negative experiences, often failing to employ adaptive interpersonal emotion regulation strategies. No research to date has examined the link between negative urgency and use of interpersonal emotion regulation. Assessing the underlying neural mechanisms of interpersonal emotion regulation could further bolster our understanding of how individuals high in negative urgency fail to engage in adaptive uses of interpersonal emotion regulation. 

References:
Cahn, D. D. (1992). Conflict in intimate relationships. New York, NY: Guilford Press.
Laursen, B. (1995). Conflict and social interaction in adolescent relationships. Journal of Research on Adolescence, 5(1), 55-70.
McNulty, J. K., O'Mara, E. M., and Karney, B. R. (2008). Benevolent cognitions as a strategy of relationship maintenance: "Don't sweat the small stuff"....But it is not all small stuff. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 94(4), 631-646. http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.94.4.631
Richards, J. M., Butler, E. A., and Gross, J. J. (2003). Emotion regulation in romantic relationships: The cognitive consequences of concealing feelings. Journal of Social and Personal Relationships, 20(5), 599-620.
Shantz, C. U. (1987). Conflicts between children. Child Development, 2, 283-305.
Whiteside, S. P., & Lynam, D. R. (2001). The Five Factor Model and impulsivity: Using a structural model of personality to understand impulsivity. Personality and Individual Differences, 30(4), 669-689.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Negative urgency will be inversely associated with effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect. Specifically, higher negative urgency scores will be associated with lower effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect scores.

Hypothesis 2: Effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect will be inversely associated with higher self-reported intimate partner aggression. Such that, higher effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect scores will be associated with lower self-reported intimate partner aggression.

Hypothesis 3: Effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect will be negatively associated with greater behavioral intimate partner aggression. Such that, higher effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect scores will be associated with lower levels of aggression toward ones romantic partner.

Hypothesis 4: Negative urgency will be positively associated with greater intimate partner aggression through less effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect.

Hypothesis 5: Negative urgency will be positively associated with greater intimate partner aggression through less ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC) activation while viewing negative images. 

Exploratory: Intimate partner conflict and effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect will be associated with other markers of relationship functioning and behaviors related to positive relationship functioning (e.g., relationship satisfaction, emotion regulation, attachment style, perspective taking, mindfulness, self-control, personality, well-being, alcohol use).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The over-arching study design is a series of dyadic indirect effects.

q9.value: We will use reverse counterbalancing to determine which partner (within the dyad) will complete the intrapersonal image viewing task first to ensure the same gender participants were not receiving the same order of tasks (i.e., majority of male partners completing the intrapersonal image viewing task first). The image viewing tasks consists of three types of images: positive, negative, and neutral (25 of each category). Therefore, the order of these types of images were randomized such that participants were not all viewing the images in the same order. The interpersonal image viewing task (where couples view and rate images together) consisted of a different set of positive, negative, and neutral images (25 images each). This second set of images were first randomized such that the order of each category of image (positive, negative, neutral) were random, but then each partner viewed and rated the same order at the same time.

question.value:
Inclusion Criteria: 
- In a committed and exclusive romantic relationship for at least three months without any breaks
- 18-35 years old

Exclusion Criteria:
- non-right hand dominance
- metal in their head
- history of neurological disorder
- a head injury
- an illness that caused a brain injury
- other brain related conditions
- sensitive scalp

-----Screening Survey------
Prospective participants will follow a link (obtained from the SONA website or from study personnel if they were recruited from the community) to an online survey run by Qualtrics. This survey will assess key information to ensure that participants are comfortable wearing the functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) equipment and will provide high-quality brain data (see above exclusion criteria). The screener survey link will have two sections, one for each partner to complete. They will be instructed to complete their section independently. At the end of the survey, participants will provide their full name and email address so we can provide them with the code to sign up for the lab study via the SONA website. Community members will be contacted by email to schedule their study session. Unqualified participants will not be contacted by these means. Instead, they will receive a message at the end of the screener indicating they were not eligible for the study and to feel free to contact the study Principle Investigator (PI) with any questions.

-----Laboratory Session-----
After participants are screened for eligibility, both romantic partners will be scheduled to come into a laboratory located at one of the lab spaces owned by the Psychology Department to complete the study procedures. All research assistants (RA) associated with the study will be trained and supervised by the Student Investigator (Alexandra Martelli) and PI (Dr. Chester) and will be required to complete a minimum of four mock assessment training sessions before running any actual participants through these procedures. Each study session will be run by two research assistants (RA; one will be referred to as the 'Lead RA' and the other will be referred to as the 'Support RA'). Each RA will be assigned to work with one of the romantic partners in the dyad.

-----Baseline Questionnaires-----
Upon participants entering the lab space, the Lead RA will inform the couple they will be separated for the majority of the study session, and ask them to turn off their cellular devices until the study session is complete. Participants will immediately be separated into two different study rooms to complete the informed consent procedures. Those who consent to participate will then complete a basic demographic questionnaire along with part one of the self-report measures (UPPS-P Impulsivity Scale, Effective Interpersonal Regulation of Negative Affect Scale, Interpersonal Regulation Questionnaire, Interpersonal Regulation Interaction Scale). All participants will also complete a brief questionnaire that asks about caffeine consumption and medications in the past 24 hours to control for abnormalities in fNIRS data collection due to caffeine use or medications use.

-----Image Viewing Task-----
After completing the first questionnaire portion of the study, one romantic partner (partner #1, determined via counterbalance) will be set up first with the fNIRS equipment to complete the Image Viewing Task while their romantic partner (partner #2) completes part two of the questionnaires. The remaining questionnaires will be asked at this time for the exception of the aggression questionnaires. These questionnaires will be saved until the end of the session, after participants complete the competitive reaction time game. During the fNIRS recording, participants will view various images (positive, negative, and neutral) alone and with their partner (i.e., Image Viewing Task). Following each image will be two rating scales (positive, negative) and participants will be instructed to rate how positive and negative each image is from 1 (not at all) to 4 (extremely).

-----Types of Images -----
Prior to selection of images, all explicit, erotic images were taken out of the set of images. Then, images were selected based on hedonic valence (unpleasant to pleasant) and arousal ratings. Valence ratings range from 1 (unpleasant: unhappy, annoyed, etc.) to 9 (pleasant: happy, hopeful, etc.). Arousal ratings range from 1 (calm) to 9 (excited). IAPS includes more than 1,000 exemplars of human experience - joy, sadness, fear, anger, threatening, attractive, ugly, houses, art objects, household objects, funerals, pollution, dirty toilets, cityscapes, seascapes, sports events, photojournalism from wars and disasters, sick patients, baby animals, loving families, waterfalls, children playing. Most importantly, this international affective pictorial system encourages replication and extension of published research using the same or similar stimulus materials, which promotes increase in scientific knowledge. 

Conditions will be presented using a rapid event-related design in a pseudo-randomized order for all conditions (intrapersonal for both partners as well as interpersonal). Based on similar fNIRS stimuli presentation designs (Glotzbach et al., 2011), each task condition will consist of a total of 75 trials (25 positive, 25 negative, 25 neutral; within-subjects). Each trial will consist of viewing a picture for 3s (Glotzbach et al., 2011), positive rating scale (3s), negative rating scale (3s), and an intertrial interval period displaying a fixation cross (jittered at 500ms and 750ms). After each image, participants will provide two emotion ratings: positive and negative. Each emotion rating scale is a 4-point Likert type scale rated from 1 (not at all) to 4 (extremely), with higher ratings corresponding to greater positive (or negative) ratings. The contrast of interest for analyses will focus on the negative image trials minus the positive and neutral image trials because negative urgency is associated with self-control failure in the face of negative emotional stimuli (Chester et al., 2016). This contrast will allow us to capture blood oxygenated level dependent (BOLD) signal (from fNIRS recording) specific to negative stimuli while controlling for all other stimuli.

The order of the Image Viewing Task will be as follows: partner #1 views images alone (while partner #2 completes part two of the questionnaires), then they switch so partner #2 views images alone (while partner #1 completes questionnaires), and finally both partners view images together. Once partner #2 is set up with the fNIRS equipment they will keep it on for the remainder of the study session, including during the competitive reaction time game (which follows the Image Viewing Task). There is only one fNIRS cap, so whoever is partner #2 will have the fNIRS cap on from the start of their solo Image Viewing Task to the end of the competitive reaction time game. The RA working with partner #2 will take their fNIRS cap off after the end of the competitive reaction time game.

For the co-viewing condition, partners will be reunited by the Support RA bringing their participant into the Lead RA's study room. The Support RA will set their participant up next to their romantic partner at an adjacent computer to view the images together. Both participants will receive instructions once more to view each image and then rate how positive and negative each image is from 0 (not at all) to 4 (extremely). Once all conditions of the Image Viewing Task are complete, the couples will be separated again to complete the competitive reaction time game.

------fNIRS-----

The fNIRSport (NIRx Medical Technologies, LLC, New York, USA) equipment will be utilized for the neuroimaging component of the study. This non-invasive procedure does not have any risks associated with the device, although participants with sensitive scalps will be not be eligible to participate because the slight pressure of the fNIRS cap would be uncomfortable. The fNIRS system will consist of 16 light sources and 16 detectors, with a 3cm space between probes, comprising 48 channels. 

The device is fitted to each partner by first measuring the circumference around their head to determine the size of the cap. There are three sizes: 54 (small), 56 (medium), 58 (large). The cap will be positioned over the frontal and frontotemporal area with its lowest-row center optode at the electrode position FPz, according to the international 10-20 system for EEG (Jasper, 1958). Once the cap is fitted to each participant the placement and distance between the optodes will be adjusted and secured. A black shower cap will be secured over the top of the optodes and around the head to shield from any extraneous light. Each LED light source emits light at two wavelengths (760 and 850 nm). Data will be recorded at 7.81 Hz. 

-----Aggression Task (aka Competitive Reaction Time Game)-----
Both romantic partners will be told the cover story that they will be playing a competitive reaction time game with each other and a stranger. Each RA will tell their respective dyad member that they will be playing against each other and a stranger, and they will be placed in separate rooms as to not distract one another from playing the game. In reality, they will each be playing against the computer with preprogrammed wins and losses. This game will take the form of a competitive reaction-time task in which the winner could deliver aversive noise to the loser through headphones. The aggression task will consist of a total of 32 trials, with each round consisting of 8 trials. Participants will play against each opponent for two rounds. Prior to each trial, participants will be instructed to set the volume of the noise blast their opponent would receive if the participant won the round, ranging from Level 1 (60 dB) to Level 4 (105 dB) in 15 dB intervals, not to exceed 105 dB. After each trial, participants will see the intensity settings their opponents set for them and then whether they won or lost. 

The task is set to have the participants win four trials and lose four trials against each opponent (determined randomly, despite being told that their performance was what determined the outcome of each trial). All noise levels will be calibrated beforehand such that, although the noise is unpleasant, no damage to the ear will occur. The volume that the participant sets for their partner serves as our measure of aggression.

-----Final Questionnaire Portion -----
After playing the Competitive Reaction Time Game "together," participants will complete the final few questionnaires that measure aggressive tendencies. These self-report measures will provide evidence of participants typical conflict or aggressive tendencies.

-----Debriefing-----
Prior to debrief, research assistants will check qualtrics for overt violence items on the Abuse Within Intimate Relationships Scale (items 16-26). If any of these items are endorsed an additional three questions need to be asked participants (see below).

Participants will remain separated for the final debrief. First, participants will be asked three suspicion questions. Specifically, participants will be asked, "What did you think the study was about?", "Did anything seem strange or unusual to you?" and “Did you feel like you were being tricked at all during the study procedures?” Next, participants will be fully debriefed and explained the true nature of the study. Following the debrief, participants will be asked to answer a couple questions to assess whether it is safe to reunite the romantic partners following the conflict paradigm. Participants will be asked two questions, “Are you feeling any lingering feelings of anger or frustration towards your romantic partner?” and “Do you feel like you might want to hurt your partner if you saw them in a few moments?” If participants say yes to either question, indicating it is unsafe to reunite them with their romantic partner, the respective RA will give them an opportunity to work through those feelings by instructing them to re-read the debriefing form provided while the RA steps out of the room to give the participant space. The RA will return after a couple of minutes to check back in with the participant and ask the debriefing questions again. Study procedures are expected to be no more or less upsetting than everyday life, but resources will be available to participants for support or for referral to counseling services if appropriate.

---If AWIRS items are endorsed, three additional open ended questions will be asked ---

Research assistants will explain to the participant they are going to ask three open ended questions

1. What are your fears and concerns regarding being reunited with your romantic partner?
2. What specific stresses did you experience from the study procedures today that will impact your safety with your
romantic partner?
3. Do you think any threats will be made against you after completing these study procedures and if so, what threats?

*If participants express any concern being reunited with their partner we will immediately provide them with contact information for the YWCA's confidential 24-hour domestic violence hotline that can provide free transportation (pre-paid ubers) and emergency housing, as well as put them in touch with resources. We will also put them in contact with the VCU Well's dating violence advocacy services. If the romantic partners both feel ready to be reunited, the Lead RA will finish the debrief process together. The Lead RA will thank both romantic partners for participating in the study, and ask them both together, one more time, if they feel angry or aggressive towards each other. Finally, the Support RA will lead both romantic partners out of the lab.

VCU participants that are completing the study for credit will be granted their credit immediately following the session. Any non-VCU participants will be placed into a raffle for two chances to win $50 at the end of the study.

q13.value:
Following the recommendation of Fritz and MacKinnon (2007), a sample size of 148 was deemed large enough to achieve adequate power (i.e., .80) when testing for bias-corrected and accelerated, bootstrapped indirect effects. The effect size estimate we adopted for this determination was based on the combined effect sizes (established from prior research) for path α (independent variable to the mediator; H indicating a moderate effect size = .26; Cyders et al., 2014) and path β (mediator to the dependent variable; H indicating a moderate effect size = .26; Barnes et al., 2007).

Given the multi-level nature of the data, this sample size estimate will be sufficient to test for indirect effects in a multilevel framework (McNeish, 2017). Therefore, we will aim to recruit 74 couples (or 148 participants) in the present study.

Due to the inclusion and exclusion criteria it is expected that roughly 15%-20% of participants who are screened for the study will not be eligible to participate. Therefore, it is expected that there will be 200 potential participants who will complete partial study procedures (i.e. screening).

See information in above response.

Additionally, since this project is a dissertation project the arbitrary constraint of time is an important factor that will determine the sample size.

q15.value: Data collection will end when the sample size reaches 74 couples and/or time does not allow for more data collection to defend the student investigators' dissertation.

question.value:
1. Image Viewing Task: Whether participants are viewing images alone (intrapersonal condition) or with their romantic partner (interpersonal condition), is experimentally manipulated, as well as the type of images they view: negative, neutral, or positive. 

Participants will view images from the International Affective Picture System (IAPS; Lang, Bradley, and Cuthbert, 2008), which includes standardized images normed for valence and arousal levels intended to evoke emotional responses. Negative images will be selected based on the minimum criterion that they are rated less than four, with arousal ratings expected to be around five (see Mikels et al., 2005 for review of emotional category data of IAPS). The neutral midpoint is five, so all neutral images will be within ½ rating unit of the midpoint, with lower expected arousal ratings compared to negative and positive images (~3). Positive images will be selected based on valence ratings greater than six, with arousal ratings expected to be around five. So this task takes a 2 (viewing condition: intrapersonal or interpersonal) x 3 (image condition: negative, neutral, or positive) within-subjects design.

2. Aggression Target: Whether participants are aggressing against their romantic partner or a stranger, is experimentally manipulated, as well as whether the given interaction partner is highly provocative (selects a 3 or 4 volume noise blast) or less provocative (selects a 1 or 2 volume noise blast), so this task takes a 2 (aggression target: romantic partner or stranger) x 2 (provocation: high or low) within-subjects design.

Demographics and Relationship Status - Participants will report their current age, gender/ethnic/racial identity, current romantic relationship status and the duration of that relationship.

Taylor Aggression Paradigm (TAP) - aggressive behavior will be measured by the volume of sound blasts that participants select for their opponent from 1 (lowest sound blast) to 4 (highest sound blast),  targeted at either their romantic partner or opposite sex stranger. These settings will be averaged together for each participant, separately for each of the 2 targets. This task will proceed over 32 trials. Each trial will begin with a fixation cross to model baseline neural activation, followed by a volume-setting screen (participants have three seconds to respond), followed by a competition screen (3 seconds each, followed by a screen indicating their opponent's volume setting (3 seconds each), and ending with a screen indicating whether they won or lost the competition (3 seconds each). Trials are presented in blocks of 8 (2 blocks per aggression target), each block is preceded by a screen instructing participants who the subsequent 8 trials will be played against (3 seconds each). Trials are randomly assigned to include high or low provocation from participants' opponents.

Questionnaires:
1. Negative Urgency will be assessed using the negative urgency subscale of the 59-item version of the UPPS-P Impulsivity Scale (UPPS-P; Whiteside and Lynam, 2001). Participants will be asked to rate the extent of their agreement with statements on a 4-point Likert Scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree).  

2.Intimate Partner Aggression:

a. Abuse Within Intimate Relationships Scale (AWIRS; Borjesson, Aarons, and Dunn, 2003)- 26-item scale in which participants report how frequently they have abused their partner, from 0 (Never) to 7 (More than once a day). AWIRS consists of five subscales: emotional abuse, deception, verbal abuse, overt violence, and restrictive violence. 

b. Conflict Tactics Scale - 20-item scale in which participants report how frequently they have abused their partner, from 0 (This never happened) to 7 (Not in the past year, but it did happen before). This scale measures both self and partner reports of intimate partner aggression perpetration. 

c. Forms and Functions of Intimate Partner Aggression - 36-item self-report of the forms (overt, relational) and functions (reactive, proactive) of intimate partner aggression scored on a 1 (not at all) - 4 (completely true) scale with higher scores indicating higher propensity for IPA perpetration. The items break down to six sub-scales with six items per sub-scale with Items 1-6 capturing overt IPA, 7-12 reactive overt, 13-18 proactive overt, 19-24 relational, 25-30 reactive relational, and 31-36 capturing proactive relational aggression.

3. Efficacy of Interpersonal Regulation of Negative Affect will be measured using the following two scales:

a. Negative efficacy will be measured using the negative efficacy subscale of the 16-item Interpersonal Regulation Questionnaire (IRQ; Williams, Morelli, Ong, and Zaki, 2018). The IRQ assesses subjective reports of four characteristics of interpersonal emotion regulation: the tendency to use interpersonal emotion regulation for positive and negative emotions and their efficacy (i.e., how well interpersonal emotion regulation strategies work to regulate their emotions), which creates four subscales: Negative-Tendency, Negative-Efficacy, Positive-Tendency, and Positive-Efficacy.  Each subscale consists of four items that respondents rate the extent to which they agree with various statements on a 7-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

b. Effective Intrinsic Interpersonal Regulation of Negative Affect Scale (EIIRNAS) is a 16-item measure that assesses the extent to which social interaction is effective in dampening or modifying the expression or experience of negative affect. Each item is rated from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).

Negative emotion ratings from the intrapersonal and interpersonal image viewing tasks will be combined into an index of "effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect." First, we will take the average of the negative emotion ratings from each condition separately (intrapersonal, interpersonal). Second, we will subtract the average negative emotion rating from intrapersonal from the average negative emotion rating from the interpersonal condition to compute an index of effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect. The same method will be applied to the positive and neutral emotion ratings to use to test whether our predictions are unique to negative affect. 

1. Negative Urgency will be assessed using the negative urgency subscale of the 59-item version of the UPPS-P Impulsivity Scale (UPPS-P; Whiteside and Lynam, 2001). We will take the mean of the 12 negative urgency items. 

2.Intimate Partner Aggression:

a. Abuse Within Intimate Relationships Scale (AWIRS; Borjesson, Aarons, and Dunn, 2003)- 26-item scale in which participants report how frequently they have abused their partner, from 0 (Never) to 7 (More than once a day). We will take the mean of each subscale:  emotional abuse (7 items), deception (4 items), verbal abuse (5 items), overt violence (7 items), and restrictive violence (3 items). 

b. Conflict Tactics Scale - 20-item scale in which participants report how frequently they have abused their partner, from 0 (This never happened) to 7 (Not in the past year, but it did happen before). We will take the mean of the 10 self-oriented items to compute a self index of intimate partner aggression and take the mean of the 10 partner-oriented items to compute a partner index of intimate partner aggression.

c. Forms and Functions of Intimate Partner Aggression -  We will take the average of each six-item subscale: overt IPA, reactive overt, proactive overt, relational, reactive relational, and  proactive relational aggression.

3. Efficacy of Interpersonal Regulation of Negative Affect will be measured using the following two scales:

a. Negative efficacy will be measured using the negative efficacy subscale of the 16-item Interpersonal Regulation Questionnaire (IRQ; Williams, Morelli, Ong, and Zaki, 2018). We will take the average of each 4-item subscale: Negative-Tendency, Negative-Efficacy, Positive-Tendency, and Positive-Efficacy.  

b. Effective Intrinsic Interpersonal Regulation of Negative Affect Scale (EIIRNAS) - We will compute a mean score for this scale.

Overall Data Analytic Plan: In order to account for the dyadic nature of the data, the present study will use an indirect effects approach to test the hypotheses in a multilevel framework where individuals (level 1) are nested within couples (level 2). In each model, the first step will estimate and test the total effect (c) of the independent variable (x) on the dependent variable (y). The second step will test the effects of the independent variable (x) on the mediating variable (m). Finally, the third step will test the effects of the mediating variable (m) and independent variable (x) on the dependent variable (y). 

Following recommended procedures (Kenny et al., 2006), gender will be contrast-coded (-1 = men, 1 = women). Behavioral aggression and self-reported aggression are the outcome measures of interest. Separate indirect effect models will be run predicting each aggression outcome measure from negative urgency. In addition, each model will be run using self-reported effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect and VMPFC activation (while viewing negative images) as mediators, for a total of four separate indirect effect models run for two mediators and two outcome variables. 

Analyses will be conducted using the LME4 package (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, and Walker 2014) for R (R Core Team 2015). This package provides functions to fit and analyze linear mixed models, generalized linear mixed models, and nonlinear mixed models.

----fNIRS Data -----

The NIRStar acquisition software (NIRx Medical Technologies, LLC, New York, USA) will be used to record blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) response using fNIRS and to assess its signal-to-noise ratio. Neuronal activity is associated with changes in localized cerebral blood flow. The HOMER3 data analysis package in Matlab will be used for all subsequent preprocessing and analysis. Head or skin movement can cause decoupling between the optode and scalp, resulting in abrupt changes in the amplitude of the received signal. Raw data will be visually inspected for spike artifacts and faulty channels, and if any are detected, they will be removed for future analyses. Following the recommendation of Burns and Lieberman (2019), we will run a principle components analysis for motion correction to discard noisy components. The modified Beer-Lambert law (MBLL) will be used to compute estimates of changes in oxyhemoglobin (O2Hb) and deoxyhemoglobin (dHB) levels from the frequency-filtered data relative to baseline (Dixon-Gordan, Bernecker, Christensen, 2015; Sassaroli and Fantini, 2004). Increases of O2Hb, as well as decreases of dHB, are indicators of cortical activity (Obrig and Villringer, 2003). To remove baseline drift and physiological noise, band-pass filtering will be used with a low cutoff frequency of 0.01 Hz and a high cutoff frequency of 0.10 Hz.  

Recommended preprocessing pipeline summary:
1) Visually inspect "bad channels" and remove
2) Identify windows of motion artifact
3) Principle Components Analysis (PCA) motion correction
4) MBLL conversion
5) Frequency filtering
*Matlab scripts from Shannon Burns (https://github.com/smburns47) will be modified to fit our study design and will later be uploaded and shared.
	
The preprocessed fNIRS time series from the Image Viewing Task will be analyzed in an event-related manner with a model-based approach applying a two-level general linear model (GLM).

First level (within-participants). First, each participant’s BOLD signal will be modeled with a fixed-effects analysis, which will separately model each image condition (negative, positive, neutral) and condition order (Intrapersonal Emotion Regulation – viewing images alone, Interpersonal Emotion Regulation – co-viewing images) as regressors using Gaussian hemodynamic response functions (HRF) with a temporal derivative. A linear contrast will compare image conditions (Negative and Positive + Neutral images). This linear contrast was selected because at the root of negative urgency is self-regulatory failure in response to negative affect. Thus, it is appropriate to isolate BOLD response to negative images, controlling for BOLD response to images in general and positively-valenced affective images. As well as viewing condition (Interpersonal and Intrapersonal). This contrast allows us to isolate BOLD response to images that were co-viewed with a romantic partner (Interpersonal Emotion Regulation), controlling for BOLD responses to viewing images alone (Intrapersonal Emotion Regulation). 

Second level (between-participants).  Each participant's time series from the first step will be fed into a group-level, mixed effects GLM. Brain hemodynamic changes over time will be extracted for the main effect of Negative & Positive + Neutral contrast and Interpersonal and Intrapersonal Emotion Regulation contrast. The VMPFC (fNIRS channels associated with Brodmann area 10, 14, 25, and 32; Phelps, Delgado, Nearing, & LeDoux, 2004) as our region of interest (ROI) will be extracted according to the experimental design. The Negative and Positive + Neutral contrast during Interpersonal and Interpersonal contrast will be modeled in a bias-corrected and accelerated, bootstrapped indirect effect model to test the effect of VMPFC activation (during interpersonal emotion regulation to negative stimuli) on the link between negative urgency and intimate partner aggression.

Registration of fNIRS Channels to Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) Space: The virtual registration method will be applied to estimate the corresponding fNIRS channels to cortical topography (Tsuzuki et al., 2007). Structural information from an anatomical database will provide estimates of the channel positions from a standardized 3D brain atlas. This method can estimate the spatial uncertainty of channel locations due to the variability between subjects. HOMER3 has been updated to include Altas registration.

q20.value: All continuous independent and mediating variables will be centered to the sample mean prior to analysis.

q21.value: For non-fNIRS data, hypotheses will be substantiated by p values less than .05 and 95% confidence intervals that do not include zero, as well as effect size estimates that are in the predicted direction.

q22.value:
Only severe outliers that are greater than 3 standard deviations above or below the sample mean for that given measure will be excluded from the data.

For fNIRS data, we will follow the recommendations regarding excluding channels with noise.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete all of the measures for a given analysis then that participant will not be included in the given analysis.

registration_responses.q1: Responses and Behavior in Romantic Relationships
registration_responses.q3:
Conflict, a disagreement or incompatibility between two or more people, is a pervasive phenomenon (Cahn, 1992; Shantz, 1987), especially within the context of romantic relationships. Although romantic relationship conflict is normative, with conflict occurring daily (Laursen, 1995), it can also be costly (Richards, Bulter, and Gross, 2003). Relationship conflict occurs in response to personality clashes or negative emotional reactions between romantic partners (Cahn, 1992). How couples interact and resolve their disputes is a fundamental determinant of relationship functioning (McNulty, O’Mara, and Karney, 2008). Furthermore, impulsive traits, such as negative urgency, leave individuals vulnerable to conflict. Negative urgency is the tendency to act out in response to negative emotional states (e.g., anger; Whiteside and Lynam, 2001). Individuals high in negative urgency are poor at regulating their emotional reactions to negative experiences, often failing to employ adaptive interpersonal emotion regulation strategies. No research to date has examined the link between negative urgency and use of interpersonal emotion regulation. Assessing the underlying neural mechanisms of interpersonal emotion regulation could further bolster our understanding of how individuals high in negative urgency fail to engage in adaptive uses of interpersonal emotion regulation. 

References:
Cahn, D. D. (1992). Conflict in intimate relationships. New York, NY: Guilford Press.
Laursen, B. (1995). Conflict and social interaction in adolescent relationships. Journal of Research on Adolescence, 5(1), 55-70.
McNulty, J. K., O'Mara, E. M., and Karney, B. R. (2008). Benevolent cognitions as a strategy of relationship maintenance: "Don't sweat the small stuff"....But it is not all small stuff. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 94(4), 631-646. http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.94.4.631
Richards, J. M., Butler, E. A., and Gross, J. J. (2003). Emotion regulation in romantic relationships: The cognitive consequences of concealing feelings. Journal of Social and Personal Relationships, 20(5), 599-620.
Shantz, C. U. (1987). Conflicts between children. Child Development, 2, 283-305.
Whiteside, S. P., & Lynam, D. R. (2001). The Five Factor Model and impulsivity: Using a structural model of personality to understand impulsivity. Personality and Individual Differences, 30(4), 669-689.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: Negative urgency will be inversely associated with effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect. Specifically, higher negative urgency scores will be associated with lower effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect scores.

Hypothesis 2: Effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect will be inversely associated with higher self-reported intimate partner aggression. Such that, higher effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect scores will be associated with lower self-reported intimate partner aggression.

Hypothesis 3: Effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect will be negatively associated with greater behavioral intimate partner aggression. Such that, higher effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect scores will be associated with lower levels of aggression toward ones romantic partner.

Hypothesis 4: Negative urgency will be positively associated with greater intimate partner aggression through less effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect.

Hypothesis 5: Negative urgency will be positively associated with greater intimate partner aggression through less ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC) activation while viewing negative images. 

Exploratory: Intimate partner conflict and effective interpersonal regulation of negative affect will be associated with other markers of relationship functioning and behaviors related to positive relationship functioning (e.g., relationship satisfaction, emotion regulation, attachment style, perspective taking, mindfulness, self-control, personality, well-being, alcohol use).
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: We will use reverse counterbalancing to determine which partner (within the dyad) will complete the intrapersonal image viewing task first to ensure the same gender participants were not receiving the same order of tasks (i.e., majority of male partners completing the intrapersonal image viewing task first). The image viewing tasks consists of three types of images: positive, negative, and neutral (25 of each category). Therefore, the order of these types of images were randomized such that participants were not all viewing the images in the same order. The interpersonal image viewing task (where couples view and rate images together) consisted of a different set of positive, negative, and neutral images (25 images each). This second set of images were first randomized such that the order of each category of image (positive, negative, neutral) were random, but then each partner viewed and rated the same order at the same time.
